1.name: Hydrogen
1.uses: Used in fuel cells, ammonia production, and as a lifting gas in balloons.
1.description: Hydrogen is the most abundant element in the universe, forming the basis of stars and water.
1.funFact: Hydrogen was used to lift the Hindenburg airship, which famously caught fire in 1937.

2.name: Helium
2.uses: Used in balloons, cryogenics, and deep-sea diving tanks.
2.description: Helium is the second most abundant element, inert, and produced by stellar fusion.
2.funFact: Helium makes your voice sound high-pitched when inhaled due to its low density.

3.name: Lithium
3.uses: Used in batteries, ceramics, and mood-stabilizing drugs.
3.description: Lithium is the lightest metal, highly reactive, and soft enough to cut with a knife.
3.funFact: Lithium gives fireworks a bright red color.

4.name: Beryllium
4.uses: Used in aerospace, X-ray equipment, and alloys.
4.description: Beryllium is lightweight, strong, and toxic, requiring careful handling.
4.funFact: Beryllium is transparent to X-rays, making it ideal for X-ray windows.

5.name: Boron
5.discoverer: Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac & Louis Jacques Thénard
5.uses: Used in glass, ceramics, and detergents.
5.description: Boron is a metalloid with unique properties, essential in trace amounts for plants.
5.funFact: Boron is used to make green flames in pyrotechnics.

6.name: Carbon
6.uses: Used in fuels, diamonds, and organic chemistry.
6.description: Carbon is the basis of life, forming countless compounds.
6.funFact: Carbon dating uses radioactive carbon-14 to determine the age of fossils.

7.name: Nitrogen
7.uses: Used in fertilizers, explosives, and cryogenics.
7.description: Nitrogen makes up 78% of Earth's atmosphere.
7.funFact: Liquid nitrogen is used to flash-freeze food.

8.name: Oxygen
8.uses: Used in respiration, combustion, and medical oxygen tanks.
8.description: Oxygen is essential for life and the most abundant element in Earth's crust.
8.funFact: Oxygen was once thought to be part of all acids.

9.name: Fluorine
9.uses: Used in toothpaste, refrigerants, and uranium enrichment.
9.description: Fluorine is the most reactive element, forming compounds with nearly all others.
9.funFact: Fluorine is so reactive it can burn water!

10.name: Neon
10.uses: Used in neon signs and high-voltage indicators.
10.description: Neon glows red-orange in a vacuum tube, making it iconic for lighting.
10.funFact: Neon was discovered in the residue of liquid air.

11.name: Sodium
11.uses: Used in soap, streetlights, and as a coolant.
11.description: Sodium is highly reactive, igniting in water.
11.funFact: Sodium burns with a bright yellow flame.

12.name: Magnesium
12.uses: Used in alloys, flares, and medicine.
12.description: Magnesium burns brightly and is essential for life.
12.funFact: Magnesium is the eighth most abundant element in the universe.

13.name: Aluminum
13.uses: Used in aircraft, packaging, and construction.
13.description: Aluminum is lightweight, strong, and corrosion-resistant.
13.funFact: Aluminum was once more valuable than gold.

14.name: Silicon
14.uses: Used in semiconductors, glass, and solar cells.
14.description: Silicon is the second most abundant element in Earth's crust.
14.funFact: Silicon Valley is named after this element.

15.name: Phosphorus
15.uses: Used in fertilizers, matches, and detergents.
15.description: Phosphorus glows in the dark and is vital for life.

16.name: Sulfur
16.uses: Used in gunpowder, sulfuric acid, and fertilizers.
16.description: Sulfur has a distinctive smell and is found near volcanoes.
16.funFact: Sulfur is the 'brimstone' of biblical fame.

17.name: Chlorine
17.uses: Used in disinfectants, bleach, and plastics.
17.description: Chlorine is a highly reactive gas with a strong odor.
17.funFact: Chlorine was used as a chemical weapon in WWI.

18.name: Argon
18.uses: Used in welding, lighting, and as an inert shield.
18.description: Argon is the third most abundant gas in Earth's atmosphere.
18.funFact: Argon glows purple in an electric field.

19.name: Potassium
19.uses: Used in fertilizers, soap, and glass.
19.description: Potassium reacts violently with water, producing hydrogen gas.
19.funFact: Potassium is vital for muscle function in the body.

20.name: Calcium
20.uses: Used in cement, bones, and dairy products.
20.description: Calcium is essential for strong bones and teeth.

21.name: Scandium
21.uses: Used in aerospace alloys and lighting.
21.description: Scandium is a rare, lightweight transition metal.
21.funFact: Scandium is used in baseball bats for strength.

22.name: Titanium
22.uses: Used in aircraft, implants, and pigments.
22.description: Titanium is strong, light, and corrosion-resistant.
22.funFact: Titanium is as strong as steel but 45% lighter.

23.name: Vanadium
23.uses: Used in steel alloys and batteries.
23.description: Vanadium enhances steel strength and durability.

24.name: Chromium
24.uses: Used in stainless steel and chrome plating.
24.description: Chromium gives metals a shiny, corrosion-resistant finish.
24.funFact: Chromium compounds are used in colorful dyes.

25.name: Manganese
25.uses: Used in steel production and batteries.
25.description: Manganese improves the strength of steel alloys.
25.funFact: Manganese nodules cover parts of the ocean floor.

26.name: Iron
26.uses: Used in steel, construction, and machinery.
26.description: Iron is the most used metal, forming Earth's core.
26.funFact: Iron rusts when exposed to air and water.

27.name: Cobalt
27.uses: Used in batteries, alloys, and pigments.
27.description: Cobalt is magnetic and used in blue pigments.
27.funFact: Cobalt-60 is used in cancer radiation therapy.

28.name: Nickel
28.uses: Used in coins, stainless steel, and batteries.
28.funFact: Nickel gives stainless steel its strength.

29.name: Copper
29.uses: Used in wiring, coins, and plumbing.
29.description: Copper is an excellent conductor of electricity.
29.funFact: The Statue of Liberty is covered in copper patina.

30.name: Zinc
30.uses: Used in galvanizing, batteries, and alloys.
30.description: Zinc protects iron from rusting via galvanization.
30.funFact: Zinc is essential for human immune systems.

31.name: Gallium
31.description: Gallium melts just above room temperature.
31.funFact: Gallium can melt in your hand due to its low melting point.

32.name: Germanium
32.uses: Used in fiber optics and infrared optics.
32.description: Germanium is a semiconductor with a shiny appearance.
32.funFact: Germanium was predicted by Mendeleev before its discovery.

33.name: Arsenic
33.description: Arsenic is toxic and has a metallic sheen.
33.funFact: Arsenic was a popular poison in history.

34.name: Selenium
34.description: Selenium conducts electricity better in light.
34.funFact: Selenium is essential in small amounts for health.

35.name: Bromine
35.uses: Used in flame retardants and photography.
35.description: Bromine is a rare liquid element with a strong smell.
35.funFact: Bromine is one of only two liquid elements at room temperature.

36.name: Krypton
36.description: Krypton emits a bright white light when electrified.
36.funFact: Krypton is Superman's home planet in comics!

37.name: Rubidium
37.uses: Used in atomic clocks and research.
37.funFact: Rubidium’s flame test produces a red color.

38.name: Strontium
38.description: Strontium gives fireworks a brilliant red color.
38.funFact: Strontium-90 is a radioactive isotope from nuclear fallout.

39.name: Yttrium
39.description: Yttrium is often found with rare-earth elements.
39.funFact: Yttrium is used in red phosphors for TV screens.

40.name: Zirconium
40.uses: Used in nuclear reactors and jewelry.
40.description: Zirconium is corrosion-resistant and used in zircon gems.
40.funFact: Zirconium has a very high melting point.

41.name: Niobium
41.uses: Used in superconductors and steel alloys.
41.description: Niobium is ductile and resistant to corrosion.
41.funFact: Niobium is named after the daughter of Tantalus.

42.name: Molybdenum
42.uses: Used in steel alloys and catalysts.
42.description: Molybdenum enhances steel’s strength at high temperatures.
42.funFact: Molybdenum is essential for plant growth.

43.name: Technetium
43.description: Technetium is the first synthetic element.
43.funFact: Technetium is radioactive and not found naturally in large amounts.

44.name: Ruthenium
44.description: Ruthenium is hard and resistant to tarnish.
44.funFact: Ruthenium is used in wear-resistant electrical contacts.

45.name: Rhodium
45.uses: Used in catalytic converters and jewelry.
45.description: Rhodium is highly reflective and corrosion-resistant.
45.funFact: Rhodium is one of the rarest and most expensive metals.

46.name: Palladium
46.uses: Used in catalytic converters and jewelry.
46.description: Palladium absorbs hydrogen, useful in purification.
46.funFact: Palladium can absorb 900 times its volume in hydrogen.

47.name: Silver
47.uses: Used in jewelry, coins, and photography.
47.description: Silver is the best conductor of electricity.
47.funFact: Silver kills bacteria, used in ancient water storage.

48.name: Cadmium
48.uses: Used in batteries, pigments, and plating.
48.description: Cadmium is a soft, toxic metal used in industrial applications.
48.funFact: Cadmium yellow is a bright pigment used in art.

49.name: Indium
49.description: Indium is soft and malleable, with a low melting point.
49.funFact: Indium emits a high-pitched 'scream' when bent.

50.name: Tin
50.uses: Used in solder, tin cans, and bronze.
50.description: Tin is corrosion-resistant and used since ancient times.
50.funFact: Tin pest turns tin into a brittle gray powder at low temperatures.

51.name: Antimony
51.uses: Used in flame retardants and alloys.
51.description: Antimony is brittle and has a metallic sheen.
51.funFact: Antimony was used in ancient cosmetics as kohl.

52.name: Tellurium
52.uses: Used in solar cells and alloys.
52.description: Tellurium is brittle and mildly toxic.
52.funFact: Tellurium makes your breath smell like garlic.

53.name: Iodine
53.uses: Used in medicine, photography, and disinfectants.
53.description: Iodine sublimates into a violet gas.
53.funFact: Iodine is essential for thyroid health.

54.name: Xenon
54.description: Xenon emits a blue glow when electrified.
54.funFact: Xenon is used in high-performance car headlights.

55.name: Cesium
55.uses: Used in atomic clocks and drilling fluids.
55.description: Cesium is highly reactive and soft.
55.funFact: Cesium defines the second in atomic clocks.

56.name: Barium
56.uses: Used in X-ray imaging and fireworks.
56.funFact: Barium gives fireworks a green color.

57.name: Lanthanum
57.uses: Used in camera lenses and batteries.
57.description: Lanthanum is soft and ductile, a rare-earth metal.
57.funFact: Lanthanum is used in night-vision goggles.

58.name: Cerium
58.uses: Used in catalytic converters and glass polishing.
58.description: Cerium is the most abundant rare-earth element.
58.funFact: Cerium sparks when struck, used in lighter flints.

59.name: Praseodymium
59.uses: Used in magnets and glass coloring.
59.description: Praseodymium is a soft, silvery rare-earth metal.
59.funFact: Praseodymium gives glass a yellow-green tint.

60.name: Neodymium
60.uses: Used in powerful magnets and lasers.
60.description: Neodymium is a rare-earth metal used in high-strength magnets.
60.funFact: Neodymium magnets are the strongest permanent magnets known.

61.name: Promethium
61.discoverer: Jacob A. Marinsky, Lawrence E. Glendenin, Charles D. Coryell
61.uses: Used in nuclear batteries and research.
61.description: Promethium is radioactive and rare in nature.
61.funFact: Promethium glows faintly due to its radioactivity.

62.name: Samarium
62.uses: Used in magnets and nuclear reactors.
62.description: Samarium is a hard, rare-earth metal.

63.name: Europium
63.uses: Used in phosphors for TVs and LEDs.
63.description: Europium is soft and highly reactive.
63.funFact: Europium glows red under UV light.

64.name: Gadolinium
64.uses: Used in MRI contrast agents and magnets.
64.funFact: Gadolinium has the highest neutron absorption capacity.

65.name: Terbium
65.funFact: Terbium glows green in fluorescent lights.

66.name: Dysprosium
66.uses: Used in magnets and nuclear reactors.
66.funFact: Dysprosium is used in hybrid car motors.

67.name: Holmium
67.funFact: Holmium has the highest magnetic moment of any element.

68.name: Erbium
68.uses: Used in fiber optics and lasers.
68.funFact: Erbium gives glass a pink color.

69.name: Thulium
69.uses: Used in lasers and portable X-ray machines.
69.description: Thulium is one of the rarest lanthanides.
69.funFact: Thulium is the least abundant stable rare-earth element.

70.name: Ytterbium
70.uses: Used in lasers and doping materials.
70.funFact: Ytterbium has a low melting point for a metal.

71.name: Lutetium
71.funFact: Lutetium is one of the most expensive rare-earth metals.

72.name: Hafnium
72.uses: Used in nuclear reactors and microchips.
72.description: Hafnium is chemically similar to zirconium.
72.funFact: Hafnium has an extremely high melting point.

73.name: Tantalum
73.uses: Used in capacitors and surgical implants.
73.funFact: Tantalum is used in smartphone capacitors.

74.name: Tungsten
74.uses: Used in lightbulb filaments and cutting tools.
74.description: Tungsten has the highest melting point of all metals.
74.funFact: Tungsten is the heaviest element with biological roles.

75.name: Rhenium
75.discoverer: Walter Noddack, Ida Tacke, Otto Berg
75.uses: Used in jet engines and catalysts.
75.funFact: Rhenium was the last stable element discovered.

76.name: Osmium
76.uses: Used in fountain pen tips and alloys.
76.description: Osmium is the densest naturally occurring element.
76.funFact: Osmium tetroxide has a strong, unpleasant odor.

77.name: Iridium
77.uses: Used in spark plugs and crucibles.
77.description: Iridium is extremely hard and corrosion-resistant.
77.funFact: Iridium marks the asteroid impact that killed the dinosaurs.

78.name: Platinum
78.uses: Used in jewelry and catalytic converters.
78.description: Platinum is dense, ductile, and unreactive.

79.name: Gold
79.uses: Used in jewelry, electronics, and coins.
79.description: Gold is highly malleable and unreactive.
79.funFact: Gold can be hammered into sheets 0.0001 mm thick.

80.name: Mercury
80.uses: Used in thermometers and dental fillings.
80.description: Mercury is the only metal liquid at room temperature.
80.funFact: Mercury was known to ancient alchemists.

81.name: Thallium
81.uses: Used in electronics and rat poison.
81.funFact: Thallium gives a green flame test.

82.name: Lead
82.uses: Used in batteries and radiation shielding.
82.description: Lead is dense and malleable but toxic.
82.funFact: Lead was used in Roman plumbing.

83.name: Bismuth
83.description: Bismuth has low toxicity and a colorful oxide layer.
83.funFact: Bismuth crystals form stunning geometric shapes.

84.name: Polonium
84.uses: Used in anti-static devices and research.
84.description: Polonium is highly radioactive and rare.
84.funFact: Polonium was used to poison Alexander Litvinenko.

85.name: Astatine
85.discoverer: Dale R. Corson, Kenneth Ross MacKenzie, Emilio Segrè
85.description: Astatine is the rarest naturally occurring element.
85.funFact: Less than 30 grams of astatine exist on Earth at any time.

86.name: Radon
86.uses: Used in radiation therapy and research.
86.description: Radon is a radioactive gas from uranium decay.
86.funFact: Radon is a leading cause of lung cancer in non-smokers.

87.name: Francium
87.description: Francium is extremely rare and radioactive.
87.funFact: Francium has a half-life of just 22 minutes.

88.name: Radium
88.uses: Used in cancer treatment and research.
88.description: Radium glows faintly due to its radioactivity.
88.funFact: Radium was once used in glow-in-the-dark paint.

89.name: Actinium
89.uses: Used in neutron sources and research.
89.description: Actinium is a radioactive actinide that glows faintly.
89.funFact: Actinium was discovered in uranium ore pitchblende.

90.name: Thorium
90.uses: Used in nuclear reactors and gas mantles.
90.description: Thorium is a weakly radioactive metal with potential as a nuclear fuel.
90.funFact: Thorium is more abundant than uranium.

91.name: Protactinium
91.description: Protactinium is a rare, radioactive actinide.
91.funFact: Protactinium is found in minute amounts in uranium ores.

92.name: Uranium
92.uses: Used in nuclear power and weapons.
92.description: Uranium is a dense, radioactive metal critical for nuclear energy.
92.funFact: Uranium glass glows green under UV light.

93.name: Neptunium
93.uses: Used in research and neutron detectors.
93.description: Neptunium is a synthetic, radioactive actinide.
93.funFact: Neptunium was the first transuranium element discovered.

94.name: Plutonium
94.discoverer: Glenn T. Seaborg, Arthur Wahl, Joseph W. Kennedy, Edwin McMillan
94.uses: Used in nuclear weapons and reactors.
94.description: Plutonium is a radioactive metal with multiple allotropes.
94.funFact: Plutonium was used in the Nagasaki atomic bomb.

95.name: Americium
95.discoverer: Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, Leon O. Morgan, Albert Ghiorso
95.uses: Used in smoke detectors and research.
95.description: Americium is a synthetic, radioactive actinide.
95.funFact: Americium-241 is in most household smoke detectors.

96.name: Curium
96.discoverer: Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, Albert Ghiorso
96.uses: Used in space power systems and research.
96.description: Curium is a highly radioactive synthetic element.
96.funFact: Curium generates heat from its radioactivity.

97.name: Berkelium
97.discoverer: Stanley G. Thompson, Albert Ghiorso, Glenn T. Seaborg
97.description: Berkelium is a synthetic, radioactive actinide.
97.funFact: Berkelium was named after the city where it was discovered.

98.name: Californium
98.discoverer: Stanley G. Thompson, Kenneth Street Jr., Albert Ghiorso, Glenn T. Seaborg
98.uses: Used in neutron sources and cancer treatment.
98.description: Californium is a highly radioactive synthetic element.
98.funFact: Californium is used to start nuclear reactors.

99.name: Einsteinium
99.description: Einsteinium is a synthetic, radioactive actinide.
99.funFact: Einsteinium was discovered in H-bomb fallout.

100.name: Fermium
100.description: Fermium is a synthetic, radioactive actinide.
100.funFact: Fermium was also found in H-bomb debris.

101.name: Mendelevium
101.discoverer: Albert Ghiorso, Bernard G. Harvey, Gregory R. Choppin, Stanley G. Thompson, Glenn T. Seaborg
101.description: Mendelevium is a synthetic, radioactive actinide.
101.funFact: Mendelevium was produced one atom at a time.

102.name: Nobelium
102.discoverer: Albert Ghiorso, Torbjørn Sikkeland, John R. Walton, Glenn T. Seaborg
102.description: Nobelium is a synthetic, radioactive actinide.
102.funFact: Nobelium’s discovery was contested between U.S. and Soviet scientists.

103.name: Lawrencium
103.discoverer: Albert Ghiorso, Torbjørn Sikkeland, Almon E. Larsh, Robert M. Latimer
103.description: Lawrencium is a synthetic, radioactive actinide.
103.funFact: Lawrencium marks the end of the actinide series.

104.name: Rutherfordium
104.discoverer: Albert Ghiorso et al. (disputed with Soviet team)
104.description: Rutherfordium is a synthetic, superheavy element.
104.funFact: Rutherfordium’s properties are inferred from its position in the periodic table.

105.name: Dubnium
105.discoverer: Albert Ghiorso et al. (disputed with Soviet team)
105.description: Dubnium is a synthetic, superheavy element.
105.funFact: Dubnium was named after the Russian lab where it was studied.

106.name: Seaborgium
106.description: Seaborgium is a synthetic, superheavy element.
106.funFact: Seaborgium was named after a living scientist, a rare honor.

107.name: Bohrium
107.discoverer: Peter Armbruster, Gottfried Münzenberg et al.
107.description: Bohrium is a synthetic, superheavy element.
107.funFact: Bohrium exists for only seconds before decaying.

108.name: Hassium
108.discoverer: Peter Armbruster, Gottfried Münzenberg et al.
108.description: Hassium is a synthetic, superheavy element.
108.funFact: Hassium was synthesized in a particle accelerator.

109.name: Meitnerium
109.discoverer: Peter Armbruster, Gottfried Münzenberg et al.
109.description: Meitnerium is a synthetic, superheavy element.
109.funFact: Meitnerium honors the physicist who co-discovered nuclear fission.

110.name: Darmstadtium
110.description: Darmstadtium is a synthetic, superheavy element.
110.funFact: Darmstadtium has a half-life of just seconds.

111.name: Roentgenium
111.description: Roentgenium is a synthetic, superheavy element.
111.funFact: Roentgenium honors the discoverer of X-rays.

112.name: Copernicium
112.description: Copernicium is a synthetic, superheavy element.
112.funFact: Copernicium may behave like a noble gas.

113.name: Nihonium
113.description: Nihonium is a synthetic, superheavy element.
113.funFact: Nihonium was the first element named by Japanese scientists.

114.name: Flerovium
114.description: Flerovium is a synthetic, superheavy element.
114.funFact: Flerovium might be near the 'island of stability.'

115.name: Moscovium
115.description: Moscovium is a synthetic, superheavy element.
115.funFact: Moscovium was named after the Moscow region.

116.name: Livermorium
116.description: Livermorium is a synthetic, superheavy element.
116.funFact: Livermorium was named after the lab in California.

117.name: Tennessine
117.description: Tennessine is a synthetic, superheavy halogen.
117.funFact: Tennessine may behave like a halogen despite its heaviness.

118.name: Oganesson
118.description: Oganesson is a synthetic, superheavy noble gas.
118.funFact: Oganesson completes the 7th period of the periodic table.
